prompt: What does the Federal Communications Commission's public notice DA 23-36 involve?
completion: The public notice DA 23-36 involves inviting comments on Section 214 application(s) to discontinue domestic non-dominant carrier telecommunications services. The notice provides information on procedures and dates for the listed discontinuance applications.

prompt: When will the Section 214 Discontinuance Applications be deemed automatically granted according to public notice DA 23-36?
completion: The Section 214 Discontinuance Applications will be deemed automatically granted on February 13, 2023, unless the Commission notifies any applicants otherwise.

prompt: What is the deadline for filing comments objecting to the applications listed in the Appendix?
completion: Comments must be filed with the Commission on or before January 30, 2023.

prompt: How can comments about the proposed discontinuance be submitted to the Commission?
completion: Comments can be submitted using the Commission’s Electronic Comment Filing System (ECFS) or by filing paper copies.

prompt: Where should paper filings for comments be sent if using the U.S. Postal Service first-class mail?
completion: Paper filings should be addressed to 45 L Street, NE, Washington, D.C. 20554.

prompt: Are these proceedings considered 'permit but disclose' for the purposes of the Commission’s ex parte rules?
completion: Yes, these proceedings are considered 'permit but disclose' proceedings for purposes of the Commission’s ex parte rules.

prompt: What must persons making ex parte presentations do following their presentation?
completion: They must file a copy of any written presentation or a memorandum summarizing any oral presentation within two business days after the presentation.

prompt: What is the deadline for comments on a Federal legal holiday according to 47 CFR § 1.4(e) and (j)?
completion: Comments will be due on the next business day.

prompt: Why did the FCC stop accepting hand or messenger delivered filings starting March 19, 2020?
completion: To help protect the health and safety of individuals and to mitigate the transmission of COVID-19.

prompt: What is required in a memorandum summarizing an ex parte presentation according to 47 CFR § 1.1200 et seq.?
completion: The memorandum must list the presentation's attendees and summarize all data and arguments made. If data or arguments were previously filed, citations can be used in lieu of summaries.

prompt: What should individuals with disabilities do to request accommodations from the FCC?
completion: Requests for accommodations should be made as soon as possible, and can be sent via e-mail to fcc504@fcc.gov or by calling the Consumer & Governmental Affairs Bureau at (202) 418-0530.

prompt: Which entity is applying for a construction permit for a new noncommercial educational FM station in Spencer, Iowa?
completion: St. Gabriel Communications (SGC) is applying for the construction permit.

prompt: What decision was made regarding the Informal Objection filed by Kevin J. Youngers against the SGC application?
completion: The Informal Objection filed by Kevin J. Youngers was denied, the May 19, 2022, amendment to the SGC Application was denied, and the SGC Application, as amended by the May 16, 2022, amendment, was granted.

prompt: What does SGC stand for and what was their application concerning?
completion: SGC stands for St. Gabriel Communications, and their application was for a construction permit for a new noncommercial education FM station in Spencer, Iowa.

prompt: What was the result of the Bureau identifying the FACR Application as the tentative selectee of MX Group 78?
completion: The Bureau established a 30-day period for filing petitions to deny, after which, if there were no substantial and material questions concerning the grantability, it would grant the FACR Application and dismiss the remaining mutually exclusive applications, including the SGC Application.

prompt: Why did Kevin J. Youngers object to SGC’s amendments?
completion: Kevin J. Youngers objected to SGC’s amendments because he argued that no amendments on the original NCE applications were allowed after the settlement period and the 30-day petition to deny period, claiming such amendments reduce the pressure to make settlements during the settlement period.

prompt: What was SGC’s argument in response to the Objection?
completion: SGC argued that section 73.7003(d) of the Commission’s rules permits applications to be amended at any time and that the Commission routinely accepts minor technical amendments after the settlement period has run.

prompt: What does section 309(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 require for petitions to deny and informal objections?
completion: Petitions to deny and informal objections must provide properly supported allegations of fact that, if true, would establish a substantial and material question of fact that grant of the application would be prima facie inconsistent with the public interest.

prompt: Does the one-grant policy allow for secondary grants after the selection of a tentative selectee?
completion: No, the Commission explicitly upheld the one-grant policy and rejected requests to allow for secondary grants after the selection of a tentative selectee.

prompt: What does the Commission permit if an applicant eliminates mutual exclusivities in an MX group?
completion: The Commission permits additional grants from an MX group if an applicant eliminates all conflicts to other applications in the group through technical amendment, voluntary dismissal of competing applications, or a valid settlement agreement.

prompt: What was the outcome of the SGC’s May 16 amendment regarding its application in MX Group 78?
completion: The SGC’s May 16 amendment fully resolved all of its mutual exclusivities with all other applicants in MX Group 78, thus completely removing the application from MX Group 78.

prompt: Why does SGC’s May 19 technical amendment violate the one-grant policy?
completion: SGC’s May 19 amendment violates the one-grant policy because it is dependent on the Commission involuntarily dismissing the VCY Application, which constitutes a type of secondary grant the Commission previously rejected.

prompt: What was the outcome of the informal objection filed by Kevin J. Youngers?
completion: The informal objection filed by Kevin J. Youngers was denied.

prompt: Which application by St. Gabriel Communications was granted as a result of their amendment on May 16, 2022?
completion: The application for a construction permit for a new noncommercial educational FM station at Spencer, Iowa, as amended on May 16, 2022, was granted.

prompt: What does the Media Bureau's Public Notice released on December 22, 2022, seek comment on?
completion: The Public Notice seeks comment on whether the media ownership rules remain necessary in the public interest as the result of competition, pursuant to section 202(h) of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.

prompt: What are the deadlines for filing comments and reply comments for the 2022 Quadrennial Review?
completion: The deadline for filing comments is March 3, 2023, and the deadline for filing reply comments is March 20, 2023.

prompt: What is the deadline for filing comments according to the January 17, 2023 Federal Register notice?
completion: March 3, 2023.

prompt: Who should be contacted for additional information regarding the 2022 Quadrennial Review of Media Ownership Rules proceedings?
completion: Ty Bream at Ty.Bream@fcc.gov.

prompt: To whom should press inquiries be directed regarding the 2022 Quadrennial Review of Media Ownership Rules?
completion: Janice Wise at Janice.Wise@fcc.gov.

prompt: What does the Wireline Competition Bureau approve according to the Public Notice released on January 17, 2023?
completion: A revised performance plan for Arctic Slope Telephone Cooperative.

prompt: What did the Alaska Plan Order allow Alaskan rate-of-return carriers to elect?
completion: To receive support frozen at adjusted 2011 levels for a 10-year term in exchange for meeting individualized performance obligations.

prompt: When were the performance obligations for rate-of-return Alaska Plan carriers announced by the Bureau?
completion: December 23, 2021.

prompt: What authority does the Commission delegate to the Bureau regarding the Alaska Plan?
completion: Authority to review and approve modifications that serve the public interest, including deployment obligations if changes are necessary.

prompt: What did ASTAC achieve by negotiating access to fiber middle mile capacity at a lower rate?
completion: ASTAC was able to offer service at higher speeds, at least 100/20 Mbps, in many areas.

prompt: What transition did ASTAC make in Atqasuk to improve service?
completion: ASTAC moved service in Atqasuk from satellite to fiber middle mile, resulting in an additional 78 newly deployed or upgraded locations by the end of the 10-year term.

prompt: As of December 23, 2021, what did the performance obligations approved by the Bureau for ASTAC include?
completion: The performance obligations for ASTAC, approved by the Bureau, are replaced by the revised obligations that include updated wireline performance obligations.

prompt: Who should be contacted for additional information regarding the updated performance obligations approved for ASTAC?
completion: Rebekah Douglas, Wireline Competition Bureau, at rebekah.douglas@fcc.gov or (202) 418-7931.

prompt: What special notice is mentioned about the HUBB certification deadline for deployed fixed locations?
completion: The Wireline Competition Bureau announced the HUBB certification deadline for deployed fixed locations for Alaska Plan Carriers ADAK, ASTAC, and MTA, providing updates on extensions.

prompt: What action did the Wireline Competition Bureau take on January 17, 2023?
completion: The Wireline Competition Bureau granted the domestic section 214 transfer of control application for Roome Telecommunications, Inc. to Varcomm Holdings, Inc. as per WC Docket No. 22-433.

prompt: What is the significance of the January 17, 2023, release date mentioned in the public notice?
completion: The release date of January 17, 2023, is significant as it marks the 'public notice' date for the purpose of filing a petition for reconsideration, application for review, or judicial review of the Commission’s decision.

prompt: What was the outcome if no petitions for reconsideration or review are filed regarding the public notice dated January 17, 2023?
completion: If no petitions for reconsideration or review are filed, the proceeding mentioned in the public notice will be terminated, and the docket will be closed.

prompt: What FCC docket number was assigned to the notice of proposed rulemaking on location-based routing for wireless 911 calls?
completion: The FCC docket number assigned to the notice of proposed rulemaking on location-based routing for wireless 911 calls is PS Docket No. 18-64.

prompt: When are comments and reply comments due for the proposed rules on location-based routing for wireless 911 calls?
completion: Comments are due on or before February 16, 2023, and reply comments are due on or before March 20, 2023.

prompt: What was the outcome of the Domestic Section 214 application for the transfer of control of IdeaTek Telcom, LLC?
completion: The Wireline Competition Bureau granted the application for the transfer of control of IdeaTek Telcom, LLC.

prompt: How many subscribers does IdeaTek serve in Kansas?
completion: IdeaTek serves approximately 15,000 subscribers in Kansas.

prompt: How much RDOF Auction 904 support was IdeaTek authorized to receive?
completion: IdeaTek was authorized to receive $23,590.60 in RDOF Auction 904 support.

prompt: Who owns the majority of IdeaTek, and what is their ownership percentage?
completion: Daniel Friesen owns the majority of IdeaTek, with 53.21% ownership.

prompt: What is Peppertree Capital's involvement in IdeaTek?
completion: Peppertree Capital made a significant debt investment in IdeaTek and has the right to convert its debt into up to 49.5% ownership in IdeaTek.

prompt: What were the amounts of CAF Phase II Auction 903 support received by IdeaTek?
completion: IdeaTek received $6,186,881.60 of CAF Phase II Auction 903 support to serve 2,490 locations in Kansas.

prompt: What changes will occur in IdeaTek's ownership after the proposed transaction?
completion: Following the consummation of the proposed transaction, Peppertree Capital Fund IX QP, LP would own approximately 47.3% of IdeaTek, while two other funds will own about 1% each. Daniel P. Friesen’s interest will be reduced from 53.21% to 24.46%, effecting a transfer of control of IdeaTek.

prompt: Do the PCMI entities and their affiliates provide telecommunications services?
completion: No, the PCMI entities and their affiliates do not provide any telecommunications services.

prompt: Why do the applicants believe a grant of the application serves the public interest?
completion: Applicants assert that PCMI's capital investment will enhance IdeaTek’s ability to meet and accelerate service obligations for its CAF and RDOF locations under the company’s existing management.

prompt: What factors does the Commission consider to determine if a transaction serves the public interest?
completion: The Commission considers whether the proposed transaction could result in public interest harms by substantially frustrating or impairing the objectives or implementation of the Act or related statutes. They also weigh any potential public interest harms against any potential public interest benefits.

prompt: Will the proposed transaction reduce competition in the telecommunications market?
completion: No, the proposed transaction will not result in a reduction of competition as the PCMI entities are not affiliated with any domestic telecommunications carriers, so there will be no physical overlap or reduction in service providers in any markets.

prompt: Will the transaction impact IdeaTek's customers or change its service delivery and billing?
completion: No, the transaction will not impact IdeaTek's customers, service delivery, or billing methods.

prompt: Will IdeaTek's rates, terms, and conditions of services change as a result of the transaction?
completion: No, there are no planned changes to IdeaTek's rates, terms, and conditions of services.

prompt: How will the transaction affect IdeaTek’s public interest and performance obligations associated with CAF Phase II and RDOF funding?
completion: The transaction will not negatively impact IdeaTek’s obligations and will enhance liquidity for growth and investment.

prompt: What will the conversion of the loan to equity enable for IdeaTek?
completion: It will enhance IdeaTek’s access to other sources of capital and provide additional liquidity to accelerate buildout and growth.

prompt: Will the management or technology of IdeaTek change due to the transaction?
completion: No, there will be no changes in the management or technology used by IdeaTek.

prompt: What are the expected public interest benefits of the proposed transaction?
completion: The transaction is expected to provide significant additional capital for IdeaTek’s broadband expansion in Kansas.

prompt: How will the Peppertree Funds' capital infusion help IdeaTek?
completion: The capital infusion is helping and will continue to accelerate IdeaTek's planned deployment and customer benefits.

prompt: What percentage of the required locations has IdeaTek completed its CAF network deployment to?
completion: IdeaTek has completed its CAF network deployment to more than 76% of the required locations.

prompt: What is the reduced amount of IdeaTek's CAF letter of credit?
completion: IdeaTek has reduced the amount of its CAF letter of credit by 50%.

prompt: What are the expected public interest benefits of the proposed transaction?
completion: The proposed transaction is likely to yield some public interest benefits by accelerating private sector deployment of advanced services and enhancing IdeaTek’s ability to meet its CAF and RDOF obligations.

prompt: What action does the Bureau take regarding the Application discussed in the Public Notice?
completion: The Bureau grants the Application, subject to Applicants’ compliance with all applicable obligations.

prompt: When is the grant of the Application effective?
completion: The grant is effective upon release of the Public Notice.

prompt: Within what period must petitions for reconsideration or applications for review be filed?
completion: Petitions for reconsideration or applications for review may be filed within 30 days of the date of this Public Notice.

prompt: What requirement is imposed on antenna structure owners by Section 17.47(b) of the Commission’s rules?
completion: Section 17.47(b) requires antenna structure owners to conduct quarterly inspections of certain lighting systems.

prompt: What does Section 17.47(b) of the Commission's rules require for antenna structure owners?
completion: Section 17.47(b) requires antenna structure owners to conduct quarterly inspections of certain lighting systems.

prompt: Under what condition can antenna structures be exempt from quarterly inspections according to Section 17.47(c)?
completion: Antenna structures can be exempt from quarterly inspections if the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau finds that the systems include self-diagnostic features sufficient to make the quarterly inspections unnecessary.

prompt: What did the Wireless Telecommunications Bureau determine about the American Electric Power Service Corporation Monitoring System (AEPMS)?
completion: The Bureau determined that the AEPMS satisfies the criteria of section 17.47(c), making AEP's antenna structures using that system exempt from the quarterly inspection requirement.

prompt: Why is the exemption for AEPMS significant according to the Memorandum Opinion and Order?
completion: The exemption is significant because it should encourage other tower owners to invest in state-of-the-art technologies for continuous monitoring of lighting systems and control devices.

prompt: What is AEP requesting regarding the quarterly inspections of antenna monitoring systems?
completion: AEP is requesting to modify the quarterly inspection requirement to provide annual inspections for all of AEP’s monitored towers due to advancements in their monitoring system technology.

prompt: What does AEP claim about the self-diagnostic functions of its AEPMS?
completion: AEP claims that the self-diagnostic functions of the AEPMS are sufficiently robust to make quarterly inspections unnecessary, as they provide the functional equivalent of continuous inspections.

prompt: How does AEP describe its AEPMS in terms of reliability and accuracy compared to other systems?
completion: AEP describes its AEPMS as a sophisticated, proven technology that is highly accurate and reliable, similar to systems for which the Commission has previously granted waivers.

prompt: What type of alarm conditions does the AEPMS monitor and how are they classified?
completion: The AEPMS monitors various alarm conditions including critical alarms like beacon failure, communication failure, and power failure, and minor alarms like side and single marker failures.

prompt: How does the AEPMS handle alarms related to lighting malfunctions?
completion: The AEPMS captures and archives alarms within the database and follows an automated escalation protocol. If the issue isn't corrected within 30 minutes and requires a NOTAM, NOC personnel issue and record a manual NOTAM and create a service ticket for inspection.

prompt: How often does the AEP System initiate connections with monitored sites?
completion: The AEP System initiates a connection from each monitored site at least once every hour or 24 times per 24 hours. If communication is lost, an alarm is generated for a NOC Technician to manually contact the site.

prompt: What allows AEP NOC technicians to perform manual diagnostics of towers?
completion: The AEPMS allows NOC technicians to perform a manual diagnostic review from any computer connected to the internet with a secure connection to AEP’s network, enabling remote diagnostics and troubleshooting.

prompt: What procedures does AEP follow to ensure normal operation of obstruction lighting systems?
completion: AEP implements staffing and fail-safe procedures including self-diagnostic functions, programmable delays, and two-way communications capabilities. They also monitor server health at physical and operating system levels to ensure proper function.

prompt: Where and how is AEP's NOC staffed?
completion: AEP’s NOC and backup NOC are staffed with trained personnel capable of responding 24/7 throughout the year. This setup allows personnel to easily shift locations if one site is compromised, with the primary NOC located in Gahanna, OH, equipped with a backup diesel generator.

prompt: What is the purpose of AEP's backup diesel generator at its primary facility in Gahanna, OH?
completion: The backup diesel generator helps prevent power failure at the facility.

prompt: How can AEP's NOC personnel access the system if both NOCs are incapacitated?
completion: AEP NOC technicians can connect from any physical location using a secure internet connection to the Telenium alarm servers.

prompt: Why is it important for AEP to have two NOC centers?
completion: Having two NOC centers is an important fail-safe mechanism, as it allows the backup center to assume monitoring responsibilities in the event of a catastrophic failure at the primary center.

prompt: What backup power systems are in place at AEP sites?
completion: Battery backup and local generators ensure power for several days, and some sites also have solar power systems with seven days of autonomy.

prompt: What ensures the sustainability of communications if a light controller loses connectivity to the alarm server in the AEP System?
completion: The AEP System has redundant cellular gateways through the two Telenium alarm servers, ensuring notifications are sent immediately in case of an alarm.

prompt: What is the availability percentage of AEP's internal network designed for communication events to the NOC?
completion: AEP's internal network is designed with 99.999% availability for communications.

prompt: What features does the AEPMS possess that make quarterly inspections unnecessary?
completion: The AEPMS includes self-diagnostic features sufficient to render quarterly inspections unnecessary, similar to other robust monitoring systems that have been granted waivers by the Commission.

prompt: What precedent is there for granting exemptions from quarterly tower inspections?
completion: In the 2007 and 2014 Commission orders, companies like American Tower Corporation and Global Signal, Inc. were granted waivers to perform annual instead of quarterly inspections for technologically advanced monitoring systems.

prompt: How does the AEPMS compare to other monitoring systems?
completion: The AEPMS is similar to other monitoring systems previously deemed robust by the Commission, having features such as a continuous two-way link, timely problem reporting, staffed response centers, and backup procedures.

prompt: Why does the Bureau find the AEPMS safe and reliable?
completion: The AEPMS has advanced tracking mechanisms that ensure proper functioning of remote monitoring technology, offering a rapid response in case of a lighting failure, thus supporting its safety and reliability.

prompt: What impact might the Commission's decision have on other tower owners?
completion: The decision may encourage other tower owners to invest in advanced technologies capable of continuous monitoring of their lighting systems and control devices.

prompt: What is the FCC seeking comments on regarding BlueWind Medical Ltd.?
completion: The FCC is seeking comments on a request by BlueWind Medical Ltd. to waive Section 15.223(a) of the Commission’s rules for its implantable medical device system operating on the center frequency 6.78 MHz.

prompt: What is the purpose of BlueWind Medical's tibial neuromodulation system?
completion: BlueWind Medical's tibial neuromodulation system is intended to treat patients diagnosed with overactive bladder (OAB) and related symptoms.

prompt: How does the implantable device in the BlueWind System receive power and data?
completion: The implant receives power and data from the External Control Unit (ECU) through near-field inductive coupling via pulse modulation of a 6.78 MHz carrier signal.

prompt: What is the specified emission limit under Section 15.223(a) for the frequency range 1.705-10 MHz?
completion: Section 15.223(a) limits the field strength of any emission in the 1.705-10 MHz frequency range to 100 microvolts per meter at a distance of 30 meters.

prompt: Why is BlueWind Medical seeking a waiver from the FCC?
completion: BlueWind Medical is seeking a waiver to permit its system to be certified and marketed with ECU emissions that may exceed the current limit of 15 microvolts per meter, allowing for a maximum field strength of 108.8 microvolts per meter.

prompt: What is the purpose of BlueWind Medical's Waiver Request proceeding?
completion: The purpose is to develop a complete record on the issues presented by BlueWind Medical's Waiver Request and to facilitate comments and reply comments in ET Docket 23-27 as part of an ex parte communication process.

prompt: What was the outcome of the complaint against Lingo Telecom, LLC as discussed in the Order?
completion: Lingo Telecom, LLC (Lingo) was found to have violated the Commission’s slamming rules, and the complaint was granted.

prompt: What does Section 258 of the Communications Act of 1934 prohibit?
completion: Section 258 prohibits the practice of 'slamming', which is the unauthorized change in a subscriber’s selection of a provider of telephone exchange service or telephone toll service.

prompt: What are the requirements for a carrier change according to the Commission’s rules?
completion: A carrier must obtain the subscriber’s written or electronically signed authorization, obtain confirmation via a toll-free number, or use an independent third party to verify the order before a carrier change can occur.

prompt: How do the Commission’s rules limit the liability of subscribers when unauthorized carrier changes occur?
completion: The unauthorized carrier must absolve the subscriber of charges for the first 30 days if not paid, pay 150% of charges if paid to the authorized carrier, who then refunds 50% to the subscriber.

prompt: What happens if there is a finding of material misrepresentation during the sales call?
completion: The consumer’s authorization to change carriers will be deemed invalid, even with some evidence of authorization, and the burden of proof shifts to the carrier to rebut the consumer's claim.

prompt: What was the key evidence that the Commission suggested could rebut a consumer's claim of misrepresentation?
completion: An accurate and complete recording of the sales call.

prompt: What was Complainant's allegation regarding the telecommunications service provider?
completion: Complainant alleged that her telecommunications service provider had been changed without her authorization.

prompt: How did Lingo respond to the Commission's request to address the complaint?
completion: Lingo provided an audio recording characterized as a 'Quality Control Call' and a contract Complainant allegedly signed, but did not address the misrepresentation allegation or provide a sales call recording.

prompt: What did the Commission find based on the evidence available?
completion: The Commission found Complainant's allegation of sales call misrepresentation credible and concluded that Lingo failed to provide persuasive evidence to rebut the claim.

prompt: What happens to a consumer's authorization to switch carriers if based on false information?
completion: The consumer's authorization to switch carriers can no longer be considered binding.

prompt: What were the findings regarding the complaint against Lingo Telecom, LLC?
completion: The Federal Communications Commission granted the complaint against Lingo Telecom, LLC, ordering them not to pursue collection for charges incurred during the first thirty days after an unauthorized change.

prompt: What is G.I.G., Inc. liable for according to the Memorandum Opinion and Order and Notice of Apparent Liability for Forfeiture?
completion: G.I.G., Inc. is apparently liable for a monetary forfeiture of $6,500 for willfully violating section 74.788 by not timely filing a license to cover application and for engaging in unauthorized operation.

prompt: What was the purpose of the application mentioned at the beginning of the text?
completion: The purpose was to renew the Station’s license for a period of two years.

prompt: What sections of law does the NAL refer to?
completion: The NAL refers to sections 309(k) and 503(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, and section 1.80 of the Commission’s rules.

prompt: What happened to 47 CFR § 74.788 of the Commission's rules?
completion: 47 CFR § 74.788 was eliminated and found to be duplicative with 47 CFR § 73.3598 of the Rules effective October 24, 2022.

prompt: What was the FCC proceeding related to the digital transition of LPTV and translators?
completion: It was about the Amendment of Parts 73 and 74 of the Commission's Rules to establish rules for Digital Low Power Television and Television Translator Stations.

prompt: When was the KCPO-LP required to cease analog operations?
completion: The station was required to cease analog operations by 11:59 p.m. on July 13, 2021.

prompt: What did KCPO-LP apply for on March 31, 2020?
completion: KCPO-LP applied for a construction permit to transition its analog operations to digital on its licensed channel 26.

prompt: What happened to the construction permit granted on April 20, 2020?
completion: It had an expiration date of July 13, 2021, which was later extended to January 10, 2022.

prompt: What issue did KCPO-LP face in July 2022?
completion: The station went silent on July 27, 2022, due to the loss of its 'site'.

prompt: What action did G.I.G. take on July 29, 2022?
completion: G.I.G. filed a request for silent authority and special temporary authority to move operations to a new location.

prompt: What does section 74.788(b) of the Commission’s rules state about construction permits?
completion: It states that any construction permit, for which construction is not completed and no application for license or extension is filed, shall be automatically forfeited upon expiration.

prompt: When did the Digital CP for KCPO-LP automatically expire?
completion: The Digital CP expired on January 11, 2021, as the Licensee failed to file a timely application for license to cover after completing construction.

prompt: What certification did G.I.G. make in their license renewal application submitted on December 1, 2021?
completion: G.I.G. certified that the Station was operational.

prompt: What was the LPTV digital transition date and the expiration date for analog stations' digital construction permits set to?
completion: The LPTV digital transition date and expiration date of all analog stations’ digital construction permits were set as July 13, 2021.

prompt: What did the Division discover about G.I.G.'s application for license to cover its Digital CP?
completion: The Division discovered that G.I.G. had failed to file an application for license to cover its Digital CP.

prompt: When did G.I.G. claim to have completed construction of its digital facility?
completion: G.I.G. claimed to have completed construction of its digital facility in April 2020.

prompt: What actions did G.I.G. take on July 5 and 11, 2022?
completion: On July 5 and 11, 2022, G.I.G. filed two separate responses to the Division’s inquiry letter and subsequently filed a License Application and requested waiver of all applicable rules.

prompt: What was included in G.I.G.'s July and September Responses?
completion: G.I.G.'s July and September Responses included declarations from viewers, program logs, financial information related to the station's operation, a declaration from the Station’s tower owner, and photographs of the facility.

prompt: What did the Division conclude upon reviewing G.I.G.’s July and September Responses?
completion: The Division concluded that the information G.I.G. submitted was still incomplete.

prompt: What was G.I.G.'s explanation for the delay in filing a timely license to cover?
completion: G.I.G. reiterated that its failure to file a timely license to cover was inadvertent and that its request for additional time to construct in March 2021 was due to the advice of its consulting engineer and appears to have been in error.

prompt: According to section 503(b)(1)(B) of the Act, who is liable for a forfeiture penalty?
completion: A person found to have willfully or repeatedly failed to comply with any provision of the Act or any rule, regulation, or order issued by the Commission.

prompt: What violation did G.I.G. commit according to the FCC?
completion: G.I.G. willfully violated section 74.788(a) of the Rules by failing to file a timely license to cover application upon completion of construction of the Station in April 2020, and engaged in unauthorized operation for over two years.

prompt: Is inadvertence a valid excuse for non-compliance with the FCC rules?
completion: No, inadvertence does not excuse a violation or non-compliance with the FCC rules.

prompt: Who is responsible for compliance with the Commission's rules?
completion: Licensees are responsible for compliance with the Commission’s rules and for the errors of their staff.

prompt: What is the base forfeiture amount for failing to file a required form according to the Commission's Forfeiture Policy Statement?
completion: The base forfeiture amount for failing to file a required form is $3,000.

prompt: What is the base forfeiture amount for construction and operation without authorization?
completion: The base forfeiture amount for construction and operation without an instrument of authorization for the service is $10,000.

prompt: What factors are considered in determining the appropriate forfeiture amount?
completion: Factors include the nature, circumstances, extent, and gravity of the violation, the violator's degree of culpability, history of prior offenses, ability to pay, and other matters as justice may require.

prompt: What factors were considered in determining the reduction of the forfeiture from the base amount to $6,500 for KPCO-LP?
completion: The factors considered were that KPCO-LP is a low power station providing a secondary service and the lengthy period of unauthorized operation, which was over two years.

prompt: What is required for a station to commence operation according to the FCC?
completion: Stations are required to commence operation pursuant to a valid instrument of authorization from the FCC.

prompt: What governs the evaluation of an application for license renewal under the FCC rules?
completion: The evaluation of an application for license renewal is governed by Section 309(k) of the Communications Act.

prompt: What are the criteria considered by the FCC when deciding to grant a license renewal application?
completion: The criteria include whether the station has served the public interest, convenience, and necessity; whether there have been any serious violations of the Act or the Rules; and whether there have been any other violations that constitute a pattern of abuse.

prompt: What action may the FCC take if a licensee fails to meet the renewal standard?
completion: The FCC may deny the application after notice and opportunity for a hearing, or it may grant the application with terms and conditions deemed appropriate.

prompt: What was G.I.G. found guilty of in their station operations?
completion: G.I.G. was found guilty of unauthorized operation of the Station, lack of diligence and knowledge regarding the Commission’s rules, failure to file the required license application, and filing an unnecessary and inaccurate construction permit extension.

prompt: What actions did the Commission decide on to handle G.I.G.'s violations?
completion: The Commission decided to impose a proposed forfeiture on G.I.G., grant a short-term license renewal of two years for the Station, and implement additional compliance measures to review and correct future actions if necessary.

prompt: What is the proposed forfeiture amount for G.I.G.’s violations?
completion: G.I.G. is notified of its apparent liability for forfeiture in the amount of six thousand, five hundred dollars ($6,500).

prompt: What section of the Communications Act is referenced for the ordering clauses related to G.I.G.'s forfeiture?
completion: Section 503(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, and section 1.80 of the Commission’s rules are referenced for the ordering clauses related to the forfeiture.

prompt: How must G.I.G. make the payment for the proposed forfeiture?
completion: G.I.G. must make the payment by credit card, ACH debit from a bank account using CORES, or by wire transfer. Payments by check or money order are not accepted.

prompt: How can failure to provide all required information in Form 159 affect payment?
completion: It may result in payment not being recognized as having been received.

prompt: What should be entered in block number 23A of FCC Form 159?
completion: The Account Number should be entered in block number 23A (call sign/other ID).

prompt: What letters should be used as the payment type code in block number 24A?
completion: Enter the letters 'FORF' in block number 24A (payment type code).

prompt: Where can additional detail and wire transfer instructions be found?
completion: Details and instructions can be found at https://www.fcc.gov/licensing-databases/fees/wire-transfer.

prompt: What is the limit on credit card transactions with the FCC?
completion: There is a $24,999.99 limit on credit card transactions.

prompt: Where should any request for making full payment over time be sent?
completion: Send the request to the Associate Managing Director—Financial Operations, Federal Communications Commission, 45 L Street, N.E., Washington, DC 20554.

prompt: How should a written response seeking reduction or cancellation of a proposed forfeiture be supported?
completion: The response must include a detailed factual statement supported by appropriate documentation and affidavits.

prompt: To whom should filings be addressed when responding to a proposed forfeiture?
completion: Filings must be addressed to the Commission’s Secretary.

prompt: Where can instructions for completing Form 159 be found?
completion: Instructions can be obtained at https://www.fcc.gov/Forms/Form159/159.pdf.

prompt: What must the respondent submit to claim an inability to pay a forfeiture?
completion: The respondent must submit federal tax returns for the most recent three-year period, financial statements prepared according to GAAP, or some other reliable documentation that accurately reflects the respondent’s current financial status. Any claim must specifically identify the basis for the claim by reference to the financial documentation submitted.

prompt: Who received the copies of the NAL and how were they sent?
completion: Copies of the NAL were sent to Charles Poppen, G.I.G., Inc., and their counsel, Aaron Shainis, Esq. They were sent by First Class and Certified Mail, Return Receipt Requested, and also e-mailed.

prompt: What was the temporary measure taken by the Commission starting March 19, 2020, and why?
completion: The Commission no longer accepts any hand or messenger delivered filings to help protect the health and safety of individuals and mitigate the transmission of COVID-19.

prompt: What applications were granted by the Wireline Competition Bureau and the International Bureau?
completion: The Wireline Competition Bureau and the International Bureau granted two sets of applications and petitions for declaratory ruling regarding two separate transfers of control of JAB Wireless, Inc. and its subsidiaries.

prompt: What companies make up the LStar Equity Applicants?
completion: The LStar Equity Applicants include LStar Equity Company Holdings, L.P., JAB Wireless, Skybeam, and Essex.

prompt: When did the LStar Equity Transaction take place?
completion: The LStar Equity Transaction was consummated on November 7, 2018.

prompt: What was the purpose of the STA request filed by the LStar Equity Applicants?
completion: The STA request was to address the unauthorized transfer of control and to allow the LStar Equity Applicants to continue providing service for 60 days pending approval of the domestic section 214 application.

prompt: What was the outcome of the request for declaratory ruling regarding foreign investment in JAB Wireless after the LStar Equity Transaction?
completion: The petition for declaratory ruling was granted, permitting foreign investment in JAB Wireless above the 25% benchmarks in section 310(b)(4) of the Act due to the LStar Equity Transaction.

prompt: In connection with which transaction was the second petition for declaratory ruling related to foreign investment in JAB Wireless granted?
completion: The second petition for declaratory ruling regarding foreign investment in JAB Wireless was granted in connection with the GI DI Iris Acquisition Application.

prompt: What was the purpose of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Application filed in June 2022?
completion: The GI DI Iris Acquisition Application was filed to obtain approval for the transfer of control of JAB Wireless, Inc., Skybeam, AirCanopy Internet Services, Inc., and Essex Telcom, Inc. to GI DI Iris Acquisition Inc.

prompt: How did the GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants support their application for the transfer of authorizations?
completion: The GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants filed supplements on several dates including July 1, 2022, November 16, 2022, December 6, 2022, and December 13, 2022, to support their application.

prompt: What is the reference for the JAB Wireless Petition for Declaratory Ruling under Section 310(b)(4)?
completion: The reference for the JAB Wireless Petition for Declaratory Ruling under Section 310(b)(4) is IBFS File No. ISP-PDR-20221208-00012, filed on December 8, 2022.

prompt: Were there any comments or petitions in opposition to the GI DI Iris Acquisition Petition?
completion: No, a public notice was released by WCB and IB on October 4, 2022, seeking comments on the GI DI Iris Acquisition Petition, and there were no comments or petitions in opposition.

prompt: Did the 2018 LStar Equity Application face any opposition?
completion: No, the public notice released on December 14, 2022, seeking comments on the 2018 LStar Equity Application received no comments or petitions in opposition.

prompt: Who is JAB Wireless?
completion: JAB Wireless is a Colorado corporation that does not provide telecommunications services directly. It owns subsidiaries that offer fixed wireless, fiber broadband, and digital voice services under the name Rise Broadband.

prompt: What must entities be designated as to receive RBE funding?
completion: Entities must be designated as ETCs under section 214(e) of the Act, 47 U.S.C. § 214(e), to receive RBE funding.

prompt: Who are the designated ETCs mentioned in the document?
completion: Essex are the designated ETCs.

prompt: Which company is an affiliate providing service on behalf of Skybeam?
completion: AirCanopy is an affiliate providing service on behalf of Skybeam but is not a designated ETC receiving RBE support.

prompt: What types of services do the Wireless Licensees of JAB Wireless hold?
completion: The Wireless Licensees of JAB Wireless hold common carrier fixed point-to-point microwave, private Microwave Industrial/Business Pool, Industrial/Business Pool (Conventional), Millimeter Wave 70-80-90 GHz, and 3650 – 3700 MHz (NN) radio services, de facto 2.5 GHz spectrum leases, and 6 GHz experimental licenses.

prompt: Where does Rise Broadband provide fixed wireless broadband services?
completion: Rise Broadband provides fixed wireless broadband services in Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Idaho, Nevada, Utah, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and South Dakota.

prompt: What is the relationship between JAB Wireless and the Wireless Licensees?
completion: JAB Wireless is the controlling U.S. parent of the Wireless Licensees.

prompt: What interest does LStar Equity hold in JAB Wireless after the 2018 transaction?
completion: LStar Equity holds an equity interest of 71.8% and a controlling 66.6% voting interest in JAB Wireless.

prompt: Who owns or controls LStar Equity?
completion: LStar Equity is owned or controlled by LSF VIII International 2, L.P. (58% equity and voting), Lone Star Fund VIII (U.S.), L.P. (40% equity and voting), and LSF VIII Investments, L.P. (1.98% equity and voting).

prompt: What is the primary purpose of the LStar Equity Petition dated December 8, 2022?
completion: The primary purpose of the LStar Equity Petition is to request a declaratory ruling from the Commission to permit foreign ownership of JAB Wireless above the 25% benchmarks in section 310(b)(4) as a result of the LStar Equity Transaction.

prompt: Who controls LStar Equity and what percentage of voting shares do they own?
completion: John P. Grayken, a citizen of Ireland, controls LStar Equity and owns 100% of the voting shares of Lone Star Management Co. VIII, Ltd. and Lone Star Management Co. IX, Ltd.

prompt: What is the equity and voting interest distribution in LStar Equity as a result of the transaction?
completion: As a result of the transaction, LStar Equity is owned or controlled by Fund VIII Int’l with 58% equity and voting, Fund VIII US with 40% equity and voting, and LSF VIII Investments, L.P. with 1.98% equity and voting.

prompt: Who controls LSF VIII Investments, L.P.?
completion: Control of LSF VIII Investments, L.P. is vested in its sole general partner, HudCo GenPar VIII, LLC, which is controlled by the board of directors of Hudson Advisors L.P.

prompt: Does LStar Equity hold a controlling interest in any domestic telecommunications carriers?
completion: The LStar Equity Applicants state that LStar Equity does not hold a controlling interest in any domestic telecommunications carriers.

prompt: Who holds the remaining 28% interest in JAB Wireless?
completion: The remaining 28% interest in JAB Wireless is held by other entities and individuals, including JAB Wireless management and pre-2018 interest-holders, none of whom have a 10% or greater interest.

prompt: What are the ownership and control details of LStar Management?
completion: LStar Management is owned and controlled equally by Fund VIII US and Fund IX US, each with 50% equity and voting interest.

prompt: Who holds the 16% limited partner interest in Fund VIII International?
completion: PSPIB-RE Finance Partners II Inc. (PSPIB), a Canadian entity, holds a 16% limited partner interest in Fund VIII International.

prompt: Does any foreign limited partner hold more than a 5% interest in JAB Wireless?
completion: According to LStar Equity Petitioners, no foreign limited partner holds more than a 5% interest that is not exempt from specific approval requirements.

prompt: Who is the sole general partner of Partners VIII?
completion: Lone Star Management Co. VIII, Ltd. (Bermuda) is the sole general partner of Partners VIII with less than 1% equity and 100% voting.

prompt: What interest does John P. Grayken hold in LStar Equity?
completion: John P. Grayken holds 100% equity and voting interest in both Lone Star Management Co. VIII, Ltd. and IX, Ltd., and less than 0.1% equity and 100% voting interest in JAB Wireless.

prompt: Who holds interests in Partners VIII and Partners IX through wholly owned subsidiaries?
completion: The Kintyre Trust holds interests in Partners VIII and IX through its wholly owned subsidiaries Jura US and Jura Bermuda, and their subsidiaries the Jura GP Companies.

prompt: What percentage of equity and voting interests does Bermuda hold in JAB Wireless?
completion: Bermuda holds less than 0.1% equity and 13% voting interests in JAB Wireless.

prompt: Who holds less than 0.1% equity and 41% voting interests in JAB Wireless?
completion: Jura GP Holdings I Ltd. holds less than 0.1% equity and 41% voting interests in JAB Wireless.

prompt: What aggregate foreign ownership percentage is the LStar Equity Petitioners requesting for JAB Wireless?
completion: The LStar Equity Petitioners request approval of up to an aggregate 100% indirect foreign ownership for JAB Wireless.

prompt: Which entity from Canada has 6.7% equity in JAB Wireless?
completion: PSPIB-RE Finance Partners II Inc. (Canada) has 6.7% equity in JAB Wireless.

prompt: Why do the LStar Equity Petitioners not seek advance approval for foreign interests in the LStar Equity Transaction?
completion: The proposed acquisition of JAB Wireless by GI DI Iris Acquisition will remove the LStar Equity ownership in JAB Wireless, hence the LStar Equity Petitioners do not seek advance approval.

prompt: What was the outcome of the LStar Equity Petition regarding JAB Wireless?
completion: The LStar Equity Petition was granted subject to conditions, authorizing 100% aggregate foreign ownership of JAB Wireless, contingent on the removal of LStar Equity ownership through the acquisition by GI DI Iris Acquisition within fifteen days of the Public Notice release.

prompt: What happens if the conditions of the LStar Equity Petition ruling are not met?
completion: Failure to comply with the conditions may result in the termination of the ruling without further action by the Commission and could lead to monetary sanctions or other enforcement actions.

prompt: What is the purpose of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction?
completion: The purpose of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction is for Merger Sub to merge with and into JAB Wireless, making JAB Wireless a direct, wholly owned subsidiary of GI DI Iris Acquisition.

prompt: What percentage of equity and voting interests does DI Iris Holdings LP (Iris Holdings) hold in Iris Parent?
completion: DI Iris Holdings LP holds 99.5% equity and 100% voting interests in Iris Parent.

prompt: Who are the 10% or greater equity holders of Iris Holdings?
completion: The 10% or greater equity holders of Iris Holdings are Iris Opportunity LP (32.8% equity, 0% voting), GI Data Infrastructure Fund LP (20.6% equity, 0% voting), and GI Data Infrastructure Fund-A LP (39.3% equity, 0% voting).

prompt: What is the role of GI DI Iris GP LLC (Iris GP) in the corporate structure?
completion: GI DI Iris GP LLC is the general partner of Iris Holdings and Iris Opportunity with 0% equity and 100% voting rights.

prompt: Who is the general partner of GI DI Fund and GI DI Fund-A?
completion: GI GP DI LP is the general partner of GI DI Fund and GI DI Fund-A.

prompt: Who controls GI Manager LLC?
completion: GI Manager LLC is controlled by Richard.

prompt: What was the concern noted by the Commission in the Hargray/ComSouth Order regarding mergers receiving different types of high-cost support?
completion: The Commission was concerned that merging companies receiving high-cost universal service support through different mechanisms could shift costs from the fixed, model-based support company to the cost-based support company, potentially harming the efficient distribution of limited universal service resources.

prompt: Do the GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants have common control or shared costs between Skybeam and ITS?
completion: No, the GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants assert that there is no common control, shared or common costs, or consolidation of corporate books between Skybeam and ITS.

prompt: Why did the FCC decide not to apply the Hargray/ComSouth condition to the GI DI Iris Acquisition Application?
completion: The FCC decided not to apply the condition because there was separate management control, cost accounting, and financial reporting for Skybeam, Essex, and ITS, indicating no potential public interest harm from the mixed support transaction.

prompt: Who are the beneficiaries of the Magnuson Living Trust?
completion: The beneficiaries are Richard Magnuson, Allison Magnuson, Taylor Magnuson, and Scott Magnuson, all U.S. citizens.

prompt: What is JAB Wireless requesting in the GI DI Iris Acquisition Petition?
completion: JAB Wireless is requesting the Commission to find that it is in the public interest to permit post-transaction foreign ownership of JAB Wireless, the direct controlling U.S. parent of the Wireless Licensees.

prompt: What will happen to the ownership of JAB Wireless after the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction?
completion: After the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction, JAB Wireless will be directly and wholly owned by GI DI Iris Acquisition, and the Wireless Licensees will become indirect, wholly-owned subsidiaries of GI DI Iris Acquisition.

prompt: Who will be the general partner of Iris Holdings?
completion: GI DI Iris GP LLC (Iris GP), a Delaware limited liability company, will be the general partner of Iris Holdings.

prompt: Who holds the majority equity interests in Iris Holdings?
completion: Iris Opportunity LP (32.8% equity), GI Data Infrastructure Fund LP (20.6% equity), and GI Data Infrastructure Fund-A LP (39.3% equity) are the major equity holders in Iris Holdings.

prompt: Who controls GI Manager LLC?
completion: GI Manager LLC is controlled by Richard Magnuson, a U.S. citizen, as trustee of the Magnuson Living Trust.

prompt: What is the claimed percentage of foreign ownership after the proposed transaction?
completion: The GI DI Iris Acquisition Petitioners assert that the consummation of the proposed transaction will result in approximately 68% aggregate indirect foreign ownership.

prompt: What is the GI DI Iris Acquisition Petition requesting?
completion: The GI DI Iris Acquisition Petitioners request up to 100% aggregate foreign ownership interest in the proposed controlling U.S. parent, JAB Wireless.

prompt: Was there any opposition received regarding the foreign ownership interests in the GI DI Iris Acquisition Petition?
completion: No, we received no comments regarding foreign ownership interests of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Petition.

prompt: What conditions apply to the approval of 100% foreign ownership of JAB Wireless?
completion: The ruling authorizes 100% aggregate foreign ownership subject to the conditions set forth in section 1.5004 of the Commission’s rules.

prompt: Upon completion of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction, will any foreign individual hold a 5% or greater equity interest in GI DI Iris Acquisition?
completion: No, no foreign individual or entity will hold a 5% or greater direct or indirect equity and/or voting interest in GI DI Iris Acquisition and Wireless Licensees.

prompt: What must GI DI Iris Acquisition Petitioner do if a foreign group acquires more than 5% of JAB Wireless’ equity interest?
completion: They are required to seek and obtain Commission approval before any foreign individual, entity, or group acquires, directly and/or indirectly, more than 5% of JAB Wireless’ equity and/or voting interests, or a controlling interest.

prompt: What is the consequence of failing to comply with the conditions of the authorization regarding foreign equity and voting interests?
completion: Failure to comply and/or remain in compliance with a condition of this authorization shall constitute grounds for declaring it terminated without further action by the Commission. It may also result in monetary sanctions or other enforcement action by the Commission.

prompt: Under what circumstances did the Commission decide not to refer the LStar Equity Application and Petition or the GI DI Iris Acquisition Application and Petition to the Executive Branch agencies?
completion: The Commission decided not to refer the Applications and Petitions to the Agencies because the foreign ownership at issue in the LStar Equity Transaction would be removed by the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction, and the only reportable foreign ownership in JAB Wireless and its subsidiaries would be through wholly owned intermediate holding companies with ultimate ownership and control held by U.S. citizens or entities.

prompt: What is required from the GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants following the release of the Public Notice?
completion: They must file a consummation notification within three business days of the consummation of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction.

prompt: What happens if the GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants do not file the consummation notice on time?
completion: The grant of the LStar Application and Petition, as well as the GI DI Iris Acquisition Application and Petition, shall be rescinded and null and void.

prompt: Under what circumstances will the FCC pursue enforcement action?
completion: The FCC retains authority to pursue enforcement action for non-compliance with the Act or the Commission’s rules.

prompt: What was the decision regarding the domestic section 214 applications for the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction?
completion: The applications were granted as they were found to serve the public interest, convenience, and necessity.

prompt: What obligations must the GI DI Iris Acquisition Applicants comply with?
completion: They must comply with all applicable RBE requirements, including offering voice services on a common carrier basis in each RBE-supported area.

prompt: Does the public interest support prohibiting the foreign ownership of JAB Wireless?
completion: No, the public interest would not be served by prohibiting the foreign ownership of JAB Wireless or its post-transaction foreign ownership in excess of the 25% benchmarks.

prompt: What are the conditions for the grant of the LStar Application and Petition and GI DI Iris Acquisition Application and Petition?
completion: They are conditioned on the consummation of the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction within fifteen days of the release of the Public Notice, and filing of the consummation notice within three days after consummation.

prompt: What sections of the Communications Act of 1934 are relevant to this Public Notice?
completion: Sections 4(i)-(j), 214(a), 214(c), 303(r), and 310(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, are relevant.

prompt: What is the consequence if the conditions for the GI DI Iris Acquisition Transaction are not met within the specified time frame?
completion: The grants of the LStar Equity Application and Petition and the GI DI Iris Acquisition Application and Petition shall be rescinded and will be null and void.

prompt: How soon after the release of the Public Notice is the consent granted effective according to section 1.103 of the Commission’s rules?
completion: The consent granted is effective upon the release of this Public Notice.

prompt: What can be done if there is a disagreement with the Commission's decision after the release of the Public Notice?
completion: Petitions for reconsideration or applications for review may be filed within 30 days of the date of the Public Notice.

prompt: Which two types of errors did the petitioners commit in their E-Rate request for reimbursement?
completion: The petitioners committed either ministerial or clerical errors while completing their E-Rate request for reimbursement.

prompt: What can cause E-Rate request forms to be rejected or unprocessed?
completion: Inadvertent ministerial or clerical errors while completing the reimbursement forms or requesting an invoice filing deadline extension can cause the E-Rate request forms to be rejected or unprocessed.

prompt: What rule must E-Rate applicants comply with to avoid rejection of forms?
completion: E-Rate applicants must comply with section 54.514(a) and (b) of the Commission’s rules by submitting forms timely to avoid rejection.

prompt: Why was Wake County Public Schools' initial reimbursement request denied?
completion: Wake County Public Schools' request was initially denied due to lack of new facts being presented, but was reconsidered upon presenting new facts required by public interest under section 1.106(c)(2) of the Commission’s rules.

prompt: What is the consequence of failing to respond to USAC's request for additional information?
completion: Applicants who fail to respond to USAC's request for additional information within the specified timeframe risk being denied funding for their reimbursement requests.

prompt: How can E-Rate applicants seek reimbursement of eligible costs?
completion: E-Rate applicants can seek reimbursement either by submitting the FCC Form 472 (BEAR form) if they paid upfront or having the service provider submit the FCC Form 474 (SPI form) if only the non-discounted cost was paid.

prompt: What change did the 2014 Commission rule bring regarding invoice filing deadline?
completion: The 2014 rule required applicants and service providers to submit invoicing forms for reimbursement no later than 120 days after the last service day or the FCC Form 486 Notification letter date, replacing the previous USAC procedural rule.

prompt: What is the deadline for submitting reimbursement forms to USAC?
completion: The deadline for submitting reimbursement forms to USAC is no later than 120 days after the last day to receive service or 120 days after the date of the FCC Form 486 Notification letter, whichever is later.

prompt: Can applicants or service providers request an extension for the invoice filing deadline?
completion: Yes, applicants or service providers can request a one-time 120-day extension of the invoice filing deadline for any cause if the request is made before the applicable invoice filing deadline.

prompt: Under what circumstances would waivers of invoice filing deadlines not be in the public's interest?
completion: Waivers would generally not be in the public's interest unless there are extraordinary circumstances as directed by the Wireline Competition Bureau.

prompt: What must parties do if they wish to appeal USAC decisions after the 2014 rule amendment?
completion: Parties must first file an appeal with USAC before seeking a review of USAC decisions.

prompt: Before the 2014 amendment, how could parties appeal USAC actions?
completion: Prior to the 2014 amendment, a party could appeal an action or decision by USAC directly to the Commission.

prompt: What happens if USAC denies a timely-filed reimbursement form?
completion: If USAC denies a timely-filed reimbursement form, the applicant or service provider must first appeal that decision to USAC within the 60-day deadline set forth in section 54.720 of the Commission’s rules.

prompt: Are applicants required to file another reimbursement form when appealing USAC’s invoicing-related decision?
completion: No, applicants are not required to file another reimbursement form or seek a waiver of the invoice deadline when appealing USAC’s invoicing-related decision.

prompt: What did the 2006 Bishop Perry Order establish regarding clerical and procedural errors by applicants?
completion: The 2006 Bishop Perry Order found good cause to grant appeals where applicants made immaterial clerical, ministerial, or procedural errors on their FCC Forms, waiving minimum processing standards established by USAC.

prompt: What type of errors did the FCC waive in filling out Forms 470 and 471?
completion: The FCC waived ministerial, or procedural errors in completing Forms 470 and 471.

prompt: Why did the FCC decide to waive certain errors in form submissions?
completion: The FCC found no evidence of waste, fraud, or abuse and determined that rigid compliance with application procedures did not further the purposes of section 254(h) of the Communications Act or serve the public interest.

prompt: What kinds of errors are considered ministerial or clerical by the FCC?
completion: Ministerial or clerical errors include mistakes like mistyping a number, using the wrong name or phone number, failing to enter an item from the source list onto the application, or making an arithmetical error.

prompt: How long were applicants allowed to correct ministerial and clerical errors on submitted FCC Forms 471?
completion: In 2011, the Commission allowed applicants to correct errors on submitted FCC Forms 471 until the date the funding commitment decision letter was issued by USAC.

prompt: What did the Commission say about the complexity of E-Rate forms?
completion: The Commission explained that due to the complexity and detail involved in completing E-Rate forms, errors may not be discovered until significantly after a funding request was filed.

prompt: What relief did the Bureau expand regarding the FCC Form 486?
completion: The Bureau expanded relief for ministerial and clerical errors in instances where applicants submitted the FCC Form 486 with the incorrect service start date, which caused funding denials.

prompt: What types of errors have been considered ministerial and clerical in the context of E-Rate forms?
completion: Errors considered ministerial and clerical include classifying the type of service incorrectly, making calculation errors, entering the monthly charge as the annual charge, entering the discounted annual price rather than the pre-discount annual price, and miscalculating the discount rate.

prompt: What was considered in the FCC order regarding E-Rate participants?
completion: The FCC order considered several appeals from E-Rate participants who were denied funding due to ministerial or clerical errors on reimbursement forms or invoice filing deadline extension requests. It also considered appeals from those who did not respond to USAC's information requests within the specified timeframe.

prompt: What types of errors did the petitioners in Appendix A make?
completion: Petitioners made ministerial or clerical errors such as selecting an incorrect last day of service, entering the wrong billing, service, or shipping date, requesting funding for the wrong year, using the wrong service provider ID, or entering incorrect recipient of service on invoices.

prompt: Why were some petitioners' invoice filing deadline extension requests denied or not processed?
completion: The requests were denied or not processed due to ministerial or clerical errors, such as requesting an invoice filing deadline extension for the wrong funding year.

prompt: What is the main reason the FCC grants waivers or appeals for funding requests?
completion: The FCC grants waivers or appeals for funding requests mainly due to immaterial clerical, ministerial, or procedural errors, ensuring that deviations from the rules better serve the public interest.

prompt: Under what conditions can the FCC waive any provision of its rules?
completion: The FCC can waive any provision of its rules if special circumstances warrant a deviation that serves the public interest better than strict adherence to the general rule.

prompt: What do petitioners claim led to the rejection or denial of their reimbursement forms?
completion: Petitioners claim that immaterial clerical, ministerial, or procedural errors led to the rejection or denial of their reimbursement forms or extension requests.

prompt: Why does the FCC consider granting waivers in relation to the E-Rate program?
completion: The FCC considers granting waivers in relation to the E-Rate program to avoid undue hardship on participants and because rigid compliance with filing rules does not always further program purposes or serve the public interest.

prompt: Is there evidence of waste or misuse of funds in the cases considered for waiver?
completion: No, the FCC found no evidence of waste, fraud, abuse, misuse of funds, or failure to adhere to core program requirements in the cases considered for waiver.

prompt: Who has the authority to accept evidence of clerical errors and correct them on appeal?
completion: USAC has the authority to accept evidence of clerical errors and correct them on appeal.

prompt: What is USAC's authority regarding ministerial and clerical errors on reimbursement forms?
completion: USAC has the authority to accept evidence of a ministerial and clerical error on appeal and correct the issue on the submitted form or request.

prompt: Why were some petitioners' reimbursement forms denied by USAC?
completion: Some petitioners' reimbursement forms were denied because USAC directed them to refile their reimbursement form, resulting in a denial because the new form was submitted after the invoice filing deadline set forth in 54.514(a) of the Commission’s rules.

prompt: What happens if petitioners file a waiver directly with the Commission?
completion: Petitioners who filed a waiver directly with the Commission did so either based on their understanding of the rules or on the advice of USAC, but these waivers were treated by USAC as requests for the invoice filing deadline, leading to dismissals because USAC did not have the authority to waive section 54.514(a) of the Commission’s rules.

prompt: What was one reason an appeal was denied despite being timely?
completion: One appeal was denied by USAC for being filed more than 60 days after the adverse decision, although the appeal was actually timely based on the date of the FCC Form 472 (BEAR) Notification Letter.

prompt: What conditions led the Commission to waive certain rules for petitioners in Appendix A?
completion: The Commission found good cause to waive rules due to substantial hardship and confusion caused by USAC's invoice denials and incorrect guidance, which misled applicants and service providers into thinking they needed a waiver from the Commission before correcting clerical and ministerial errors.

prompt: What directive did the Commission give USAC regarding future appeals of ministerial and clerical errors?
completion: The Commission directed USAC to review appeals of ministerial and clerical errors without directing petitioners to file waiver requests with the Commission.

prompt: What should not be required of applicants and service providers if the original reimbursement form was timely filed?
completion: Applicants and service providers should not be required to submit a new reimbursement form to correct any errors, as it may result in denial due to being submitted after the invoice filing deadline.

prompt: What should E-Rate participants do if a clerical or ministerial mistake is discovered after the 60-day appeal-filing deadline?
completion: E-Rate participants should file a waiver request with the Commission seeking a waiver of section 54.720 and explain how and when the error was discovered.

prompt: What action is considered to be in the public interest regarding late or missing information requests in Appendix B?
completion: It is in the public interest to grant the appeals for petitioners who did not respond in seven days to USAC’s request for information about a timely-filed reimbursement form or an extension of the invoice filing deadline request.

prompt: What should applicants and service providers do if issues arise regarding the invoice filing deadline?
completion: Applicants and service providers should invoice early and timely request a one-time 120-day invoice filing deadline extension to resolve issues before the deadline expires.

prompt: What authority was invoked to grant the petitions and remand the applications?
completion: The authority contained in sections 1-4 and 254 of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, 47 U.S.C. §§ 151-154 and 254, and sections 0.91, 0.291 and 54.722(a) of the Commission’s rules was invoked to grant the petitions and remand the applications.

prompt: What sections of the Commission's rules are waived for the petitioners listed in the appendices?
completion: Sections 54.507(d) and 54.514(a) of the Commission’s rules are waived for the petitioners listed in the Appendices A and B.

prompt: What is USAC directed to do with the remanded requests in the appendices?
completion: USAC is directed to complete its review of each remanded request in the appendices and issue a decision based on a complete review and analysis.

prompt: Who signed the order from the Federal Communications Commission?
completion: Jodie Griffin, Chief of the Telecommunications Access Policy Division, Wireline Competition Bureau signed the order.

prompt: What is Appendix A in the document about?
completion: Appendix A lists petitioners involved in cases of ministerial and clerical errors with details such as application numbers, funding years, and dates filed.

prompt: What does the Public Notice DA 23-49 released by the FCC on January 19, 2023, announce?
completion: It announces the conclusion of the Connect America Fund Phase II auction long-form application review and provides details on authorized bids, total support amount, and coverage.

prompt: How many authorized applicant state combinations were concluded in the Connect America Fund Phase II auction?
completion: There were 195 authorized applicant state combinations.

prompt: What is the total amount of support authorized in the Connect America Fund Phase II auction?
completion: The auction authorized $1.48 billion in 10-year support.

prompt: How many states are covered by the Connect America Fund Phase II auction authorized bids?
completion: The authorized bids cover 45 states.

prompt: What is the performance tier for more than half of the winning bids in the Connect America Fund Phase II auction?
completion: More than half of the winning bids were at 100/20 Mbps or higher performance tiers.

prompt: How much funding was authorized for New York in conjunction with New York’s New NY Broadband Program?
completion: A total of $65.49 million in 10-year support was authorized for New York.

prompt: What information is made available by the Commission as part of the Rural Broadband Accountability Plan?
completion: The Commission is making available additional information from the long-form applications submitted by applicants, including the FCC Form 683 and FCC Form 5625. The Auction 903 FCC Form 683 long-form applications will be viewable through the application search feature on the Auction 903 web page, and the FCC Form 5625 long-form applications for New York applicants will be viewable on the 'New York' tab on the Auction 903 web page.

prompt: What action was undertaken on 01/12/2023 regarding the application by Telxius Cable América S.A.?
completion: Consent was given to transfer control of negative control rights over Telxius Cable América from KKR Management LLP to Pontegadea Inversiones, S.L.

prompt: Who filed the application for consent to transfer control to Pontegadea Inversiones, S.L.?
completion: Telxius Cable América S.A. filed the application.

prompt: When was the application by Telxius Cable América placed on Public Notice?
completion: The application was placed on Public Notice on March 11, 2022.

prompt: Which department coordinated the application with the Department of State?
completion: The application was coordinated by the Department of Justice on behalf of the Committee for the Assessment of Foreign Participation in the United States Telecommunications Services Sector.

prompt: What systems is Telxius Cable América a licensee of?
completion: Telxius Cable América is a licensee on the BRUSA system, the MAREA system, the Pacific Caribbean Cable System (PCCS), and the South America-1 (SAm-1) system.

prompt: What conditions did the National Telecommunications and Information Administration require for granting the application?
completion: The Commission's approval is conditioned on the assurance of Telxius Cable América and associated entities to abide by the commitments and undertakings in the December 9, 2022 Letters of Agreement.

prompt: What company is Telxius Cable América a subsidiary of?
completion: Telxius Cable América is a wholly owned subsidiary of Telxius Telecom, S.A. (Telxius Parent).

prompt: Who holds 60% equity and voting interests in Telxius Parent?
completion: Pontel Participaciones, S.L. (Pontel), a Spanish company, holds 60% equity and voting interests in Telxius Parent.

prompt: What company owns the remaining 40% equity and voting interests in Telxius Parent?
completion: Taurus Bidco S.à.r.l, a Luxembourg company ultimately owned and controlled by KKR Management, holds the remaining 40% equity and voting interests and certain negative control rights over Telxius Parent.

prompt: What percentage of equity and voting interests does Telefónica hold in Pontel?
completion: Telefónica holds 83.35% equity and voting interests in Pontel.

prompt: What will occur in the first step of the transaction involving Telxius Parent's equity?
completion: The 40% equity and voting interests and negative control rights currently held by Taurus Bidco in Telxius Parent will be acquired by Pontel.

prompt: What will be the result of Telefonica and Pontegadea's capital restructuring?
completion: Telefonica will hold 70% voting and equity interests in Pontel, and Pontegadea will hold the remaining 30% voting and equity interests in Pontel.

prompt: What does the Shareholder Agreement provide to Pontegadea?
completion: The Shareholder Agreement gives Pontegadea certain negative control rights over shareholder, board of directors, and third-party transaction matters, providing them with an effective veto over certain Pontel and subsequently Telxius Parent matters.

prompt: After the transaction, who will retain de jure control over Telxius Parent?
completion: Following consummation of the transaction, Telefonica will continue to retain de jure control over Telxius Parent.

prompt: Who holds 10% or greater direct or indirect interests in Telxius Cable América after the transaction?
completion: (1) Telxius Parent (100% equity and voting interests in Telxius Cable América), (2) Telefonica (70% equity and voting interests in Telxius Parent), (3) Pontegadea (30% equity and voting interests in Telxius Parent and certain negative control rights), and (4) Mr. Amancio Ortega Gaona (99.99% equity and voting interests in Pontegadea).

prompt: What is specified in section 1.767(g) of the Commission's rules regarding Pontegadea?
completion: Pontegadea certifies that it accepts and will abide by the routine conditions specified in section 1.767(g) of the Commission's rules, 47 CFR § 1.767(g).

prompt: What did Pontegadea certify in the declaration regarding the Commission"s rules?
completion: Pontegadea certifies that it accepts and will abide by the routine conditions specified in section 1.767(g) of the Commission"s rules, 47 CFR § 1.767(g).

prompt: Who filed the Petition to Adopt Conditions to Authorization and License mentioned in the text?
completion: The National Telecommunications and Information Administration filed the Petition to Adopt Conditions to Authorization and License, on behalf of the Committee for the Assessment of Foreign Participation in the United States Telecommunications Services Sector.

prompt: Which entities are the condition grant of the Application based upon?

completion: Rafael Arranz Ruiz is the Chief Operating Officer of Telxius Telecom S.A.

completion: José Manuel Santero Muñoz is the Director for Strategy & Corporate Development Office in Telefónica, S.A.

prompt: Which official is addressed in the letters from Pontegadea Inversiones, S.L. to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security?
